articles.headline: Active Fighting Subsides in Gaza, but the War Is Not Over, Officials Say
articles.snippet: Israeli troops have left southern Gaza, and some Palestinians returned to the area, where there was a sense of horror at the scope of destruction.
articles.abstract: Israeli troops have left southern Gaza, and some Palestinians returned to the area, where there was a sense of horror at the scope of destruction.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Israeli military’s departure from southern Gaza over the weekend has left the devastated territory in a state of suspense as active fighting there receded on Monday to its lowest ebb since a brief truce with Hamas in November.

articles.headline: German Business Is Tangled in Red Tape
articles.snippet: Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy are costing them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.
articles.abstract: Companies in Germany complain that the demands of bureaucracy are costing them time and money that would be better spent building their businesses.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Markus Wingens created the position of “energy manager” for the metal heat-treatment company he runs in southwestern Germany, his idea was to increase energy efficiency and attract customers interested in sustainability.

articles.headline: How Japan Is Trying to Rebuild Its Chip Industry
articles.snippet: Taiwan’s semiconductor giant, TSMC, is quickly remaking a farm town in Japan into Asia’s next hub of chip manufacturing with enormous government support.
articles.abstract: Taiwan’s semiconductor giant, TSMC, is quickly remaking a farm town in Japan into Asia’s next hub of chip manufacturing with enormous government support.
articles.lead_paragraph: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Company is transforming the small Japanese farm town of Kikuyo into a key node in Asia’s chip supply chain.
articles.byline: By Meaghan Tobin, Hisako Ueno and John Liu

articles.headline: As Kushner’s Investment Firm Steps Out, the Potential Conflicts Are Growing
articles.snippet: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency.
articles.abstract: Jared Kushner’s Affinity Partners has invested more than $1.2 billion, much of it in firms abroad, drawing new scrutiny as his father-in-law, Donald Trump, again seeks the presidency.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jared Kushner’s investment fund is not especially large by global finance standards. But as he gets it fully up and running, each step is bringing with it ethical issues that would only grow if his father-in-law, Donald J. Trump, should win another term as president.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Jonathan Swan and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Higher for Longer After All? Investors See Fed Rates Falling More Slowly.
articles.snippet: Investors went into 2024 expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply. Stubborn inflation and quick growth call that into question.
articles.abstract: Investors went into 2024 expecting the Federal Reserve to cut rates sharply. Stubborn inflation and quick growth call that into question.
articles.lead_paragraph: Investors were betting big on Federal Reserve rate cuts at the start of 2024, wagering that central bankers would lower interest rates to around 4 percent by the end of the year. But after months of stubborn inflation and strong economic growth, the outlook is starting to look much less dramatic.

articles.headline: Iran Smuggles Arms to West Bank, Officials Say, to Foment Unrest With Israel
articles.snippet: The covert operation, described by U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, is heightening concerns that Iran is seeking to turn the West Bank into a flashpoint in its shadow war with Israel.
articles.abstract: The covert operation, described by U.S., Iranian and Israeli officials, is heightening concerns that Iran is seeking to turn the West Bank into a flashpoint in its shadow war with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Iran is operating a clandestine smuggling route across the Middle East, employing intelligence operatives, militants and criminal gangs, to deliver weapons to Palestinians in the Israeli-occupied West Bank, according to officials from the United States, Israel and Iran.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi, Ronen Bergman and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Another Red-Blue Divide: Money to Feed Kids in the Summer
articles.snippet: Congress passed bipartisan legislation to provide families that rely on subsidized school meals with help buying food over the summer. Nearly half of Republican-led states have yet to sign on.
articles.abstract: Congress passed bipartisan legislation to provide families that rely on subsidized school meals with help buying food over the summer. Nearly half of Republican-led states have yet to sign on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The governor was firm: Nebraska would reject the new federal money for summer meals. The state already fed a small number of children when schools closed. He would not sign on to a program to provide all families that received free or cut-rate school meals with cards to buy groceries during the summer.

articles.headline: What Happened When a German Car Factory Went All Electric
articles.snippet: Volkswagen’s plant in Zwickau stopped producing Golfs and switched to electric vehicles, illuminating the risks and opportunities for factory towns and cities.
articles.abstract: Volkswagen’s plant in Zwickau stopped producing Golfs and switched to electric vehicles, illuminating the risks and opportunities for factory towns and cities.
articles.lead_paragraph: Zwickau, a city in Germany’s east, may not be as famous as Detroit, but its economy has revolved around internal combustion engines since August Horch established Audi here at the beginning of the 20th century.
